quickScenarioChallenge.scenarioStory: You're taking the PMP exam. You're 90 minutes in and have completed 80 questions. You feel fatigued and want a break. You have 10 questions you've marked for review. You're not sure if breaks count against your time.
quickScenarioChallenge.question: What's your BEST strategy right now?

options.A: Power through all 180 questions before taking any break
options.B: Take a scheduled 10-minute break now - breaks DON'T count against your time
options.C: Skip the break to save time and go back to review marked questions
options.D: End the exam now if you feel you've done well enough

ahaDebrief.correctAnswer: B - Take a scheduled 10-minute break now - breaks DON'T count against your time

insights.principle: Breaks Don't Count Against Your Time
insights.explanation: You get two optional 10-minute breaks that DON'T count against your 230 minutes of exam time. Use them!
insights.pmbokSupport: PMI Exam Format: 230 minutes of exam time PLUS two optional 10-minute breaks (total up to 4 hours 10 minutes)

insights.explanation: Fatigue degrades decision-making. A 10-minute break improves performance on remaining questions.
insights.pmbokSupport: Cognitive research shows breaks improve sustained attention and decision quality

insights.explanation: At 80 questions in 90 minutes, you're averaging 1.125 min/question (good pace). You have time for breaks.
insights.pmbokSupport: Recommended pace: ~1.3 minutes per question allows time for review and breaks

trapSection.explanation: The other options misunderstand the exam format or sacrifice performance.

trapTable.violation: Powering through 180 questions without breaks leads to mental fatigue and errors
trapTable.pmiValueBroken: Ignoring free break time that could improve performance

trapTable.violation: Skipping breaks is unnecessary - they don't count against your time
trapTable.pmiValueBroken: Misunderstanding exam format leads to suboptimal strategy

trapTable.violation: You must answer all 180 questions for scoring

checklist: ‚úÖ Use both 10-minute breaks - they're FREE time
‚úÖ Pace at ~1.3 min/question (leaves buffer for review)
‚úÖ Mark questions for review and come back to them

patternRecognition.patternRule: Treat the exam like a 4-hour endurance event. Use breaks strategically to maintain peak mental performance.

coreFramework.frameworkName: PASS FIRST - PMP Exam Strategy Framework
coreFramework.frameworkIntro: The PMP exam isn't just about knowledge - it's about strategy. Master these 10 strategic elements to PASS FIRST:

rows.action: 180 questions √∑ 230 min = 1.28 min/question. Aim for 1.3 to leave review buffer
keyQuestions: Do I have time for review?
rows.examKeywords: time management, 90 questions at 2 hours, finish with 30 min buffer

rows.action: Half or more of exam questions assume agile/hybrid context. Think adaptive, iterative, servant leader.
keyQuestions: What would a Scrum Master do?
rows.examKeywords: iterations, sprints, retrospectives, servant leadership, empirical process

rows.action: Every question presents a scenario. Read carefully, identify the domain/principle, eliminate wrong answers.
rows.examKeywords: situational judgment, scenario analysis, context matters

rows.action: When in doubt, choose answers that engage stakeholders or empower teams.
rows.examKeywords: collaborate, engage, empower, servant leader, trust team

rows.action: Know cold: 12 Principles, 8 Domains, 4 Ethics values, Agile basics, EVM formulas
PMBOK 7 is domain-based, not process-based. Identify which domain(s) the question addresses.
keyQuestions: Is this Stakeholders? Team? Planning? Uncertainty?

rows.action: Eliminate clearly wrong answers first. Choose the BEST answer among remaining options.
rows.examKeywords: process of elimination, best answer (not perfect answer)

rows.action: Take breaks after ~60 and ~120 questions. Breaks DON'T count against your 230 minutes.
keyQuestions: Should I take a break now?
rows.examKeywords: mental stamina, break strategy, free time

rows.action: Choose answers that reflect PMI's ideal world, not your workplace reality.
keyQuestions: What does PMI say is best practice?
Not: what would my boss do?
rows.examKeywords: PMI best practices, by-the-book, ideal approach

secondScenario.intro: Now that you know the framework, let's apply it to an exam situation.
secondScenario.scenarioStory: You're on question 45. You've spent 3 minutes on this question and still can't decide between two options. Both seem reasonable. You've used 60 minutes so far (1.33 min/question pace). You haven't taken a break yet.

quotes.text: The PMP examination is based on the PMP Examination Content Outline. The exam consists of 180 questions. Of these, 175 questions are scored and 5 are pretest questions. Pretest questions are used to collect data and are randomly placed throughout the exam.
quotes.author: PMI

quotes.text: The biggest mistake exam-takers make is overthinking. PMI wants to know if you can make good decisions quickly. If you're stuck between two answers after 90 seconds, make your best choice and move on. Spending 5 minutes on one question means you've lost time for 3 other questions.
quotes.author: PMP Instructor Insight

fieldInsights.title: Real-World Application
fieldInsights.insight: The exam mirrors real PM challenges: you won't have perfect information, you'll face time pressure, and you'll need to make judgment calls. The exam tests whether you can make sound decisions under pressure using PMI principles as your guide.

fieldInsights.title: Exam Strategy
fieldInsights.insight: Treat the exam like a project: Plan your pacing (Planning domain), monitor your progress (Measurement domain), manage your energy (Team domain - you're the team!), and adapt as needed (Uncertainty domain). The exam is itself a project you're managing.

memoryPalace.title: üèîÔ∏è Memory Palace: The Final Summit Push
memoryPalace.intro: You're making your final summit push - the PMP exam. This 4-hour climb requires strategy:

story.title: The 4-Hour Summit Push
story.narrative: You're at the final camp (7,800m). The summit is 180 vertical meters above (180 questions). You have 230 minutes of climbing time, plus two 10-minute rest stops that don't count against your time. Here's your summit strategy:

scenes.description: You need to climb 180 meters in 230 minutes. That's 1.28 minutes per meter. You set your pace at 1.3 min/meter to have a buffer. You mark 90-meter and 120-meter points for rest breaks.

The route changes constantly due to shifting ice (agile mindset). You can't stick to a rigid plan. You must adapt, iterate, and respond to what you find. 50% of the climb requires adaptive route-finding.

At each meter, you face a scenario: 'Ice ahead - which route?' You carefully read the terrain (scenario), identify the challenge (domain), and choose the best path (answer). You don't rush - you read ALL options.

You're climbing with a team (stakeholder & team-first mindset). When in doubt, you choose routes that keep the team together, empower team members to lead, and engage everyone in decisions. Servant leadership guides you.
Before starting, you check your gear: 12 carabiners (principles), 8 ropes (domains), 4 ice screws (ethics), agile crampons, and EVM compass. These are your foundational tools.

Each section has different terrain: Stakeholder ice, Team rock, Planning ridge, Uncertainty crevasse. You identify which terrain (domain) you're on to choose the right technique. No more old-school ITTO maps!
At each decision point, you see 4 possible routes (A, B, C, D). You eliminate obviously dangerous routes first (wrong answers), then choose the BEST remaining route - not perfect, just best.

At 90 meters (after ~60 questions), you take a 10-minute break. It doesn't count against your time - it's FREE. You rest, hydrate, refocus. Same at 120 meters. You arrive at the summit mentally fresh.

You're not just any climber - you're a certified guide (PMI mindset). You don't take shortcuts your clients back home might take. You follow best practices, by-the-book safety protocols, and PMI standards. Think like PMI, not like your workplace.

story.moral: You successfully summit using PASS FIRST strategy! You paced yourself, adapted to changing conditions, read scenarios carefully, supported your team, relied on foundational knowledge, identified terrain types, evaluated all options, took strategic breaks, and maintained professional standards. That's how you PASS FIRST!

memoryPalace.selfTest: Close your eyes and make your final summit push. Can you recall all 9 elements of PASS FIRST?
